channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2023 The New York Times Company

item.title: Russian Foreign Minister Faces Rebuke at U.N. Over War in Ukraine
item.description: The U.S. and European members of the Security Council had declined to send their foreign ministers to the meeting chaired by Sergey V. Lavrov, which was a key event for Russia’s rotating presidency. Here is what we’re covering:
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times

item.title: Civilians Flee Fighting in Sudan for Troubled Neighboring Countries
item.description: The clashes have killed more than 400 people and injured thousands more. Those displaced are streaming into nations such as Chad, Egypt and South Sudan, adding to a refugee crisis in the region.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir and Lynsey Chutel
item.media:description: Preparing to board a bus departing Khartoum, Sudan’s capital, on Monday. Even as some people have found a way to leave the most dangerous areas, many remain stuck in the city, where the conflict is most acute.

item.title: At Ukraine’s Gravesites, a Spring Ritual Hints at Renewal
item.description: A decimated village welcomes back displaced residents for a day of remembrance and hope.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer, Maria Varenikova and Mauricio Lima
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times

item.title: China’s Ambassador Lu Shaye Comments on Ex-Soviet States Drawing Ire
item.description: Remarks by China’s ambassador to France questioning the sovereignty of ex-Soviet states threatened to upset China’s efforts to balance courting Europe with supporting Russia.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.media:description: Lu Shaye, China’s ambassador to France, in 2019. On French television on Friday, he said post-Soviet nations “do not have an effective status in international law.”

item.title: Men in Military Uniforms Killed at Least 60 People, Burkina Faso Says
item.description: A prosecutor opened an investigation into the killing of about 60 people by men in uniforms of the national military. Days earlier, the authorities said they would investigate the killing of seven boys.
item.dc:creator: Elian Peltier
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: A mural in Ouagadougou, in the West African nation of Burkina Faso, where the government is investigating the killing of 60 people by men said to be wearing the uniforms of the national military.

item.title: Thaksin Shinawatra’s Daughter Enters Thailand Election
item.description: An ousted populist’s daughter seeks office, fueling concerns that the return of a divisive political dynasty may revive instability, too.
item.dc:creator: Sui-Lee Wee and Muktita Suhartono
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:description: A supporter of the Pheu Thai party with a photograph of the Shinawatra family during a campaign rally in Nonthaburi Province, Thailand, in March.

item.title: Kenyan Pastor at Center of Inquiry After Dozens of Bodies Are Exhumed
item.description: Many of the victims are believed to have been members of a church led by a pastor who is being investigated on allegations that he directed his congregants to starve themselves to death.
item.dc:creator: Cora Engelbrecht
item.media:description: Security personnel carrying a rescued young person from the forest in Shakahola, outside the coastal town of Malindi, Kenya, on Sunday.

item.title: Cans of Miller High Life, ‘Champagne of Beers,’ Crushed in Europe
item.description: Customs authorities in Belgium forcibly recycled thousands of cans of America’s “go-to lowbrow beer of choice” after they took issue with its slogan: “the Champagne of Beers.”
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola
item.media:description: In this image provided by the Comité Champagne, workers pour out the contents of Miller High Life beer cans before crushing them at a plant in Ypres, Belgium, last week.

item.title: China Accuses Liberal Columnist of Espionage After a Lunch With Diplomat
item.description: Dong Yuyu was a longtime writer and editor at a top Chinese Communist Party newspaper who had frequently met with foreign diplomats and journalists.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Wang

item.title: Ron DeSantis Praises U.S.-Japan Ties on Visit to Tokyo
item.description: The Florida governor, Ron DeSantis, had a chance to buff up his foreign policy credentials, after criticism from fellow Republicans over his comments on Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Motoko Rich and Nicholas Nehamas
item.media:description: Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida meeting with Prime Minister Fumio Kishida of Japan in Tokyo on Monday.

item.title: U.S. Evacuates Diplomats From Sudan as Exodus Begins
item.description: With hopes fading that two warring generals will end their battle anytime soon, diplomats and other foreigners began heading for Sudan’s doors.
item.dc:creator: Declan Walsh, Charlie Savage and Eric Schmitt
item.media:description: Evacuees from Sudan arriving at an airport in Amman, Jordan, on Monday. Repeated efforts to broker a cease-fire in Sudan have failed, and foreign countries have been evacuating diplomatic staff and nationals.

item.title: Chinese Censorship Is Quietly Rewriting the Covid-19 Story
item.description: Under government pressure, Chinese scientists have retracted studies and withheld or deleted data. The censorship has stymied efforts to understand the virus.
item.dc:creator: Mara Hvistendahl and Benjamin Mueller
item.category: Chinese Center for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:credit: Gilles Sabrie for The New York Times
item.media:description: The shuttered Huanan market in Wuhan in 2021. Scientists say China has kept a tight rein on data from the market, where the first large cluster of coronavirus cases was found.

item.title: What We Know About the Fighting in Sudan
item.description: The strategically important country in northeastern Africa has been consumed by more than a week of fighting between two military factions. Sudanese are fleeing and many countries are evacuating their personnel — but many people are stuck.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:description: Smoke rose in Omdurman, Sudan, as fighting broke out on Saturday between two rival military factions in Khartoum, the capital, and around the country.

item.title: Coloring History’s Gray Areas, With Strong Moral Outrage
item.description: Éric Vuillard writes short historical narratives known for their irony. His latest, “An Honorable Exit,” delves into France’s defeat in the First Indochina War.
item.dc:creator: Tobias Grey
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.media:description: Éric Vuillard likes exploring moments in history that have received little attention. His most recent book, “An Honorable Exit,” delves into the French defeat in the First Indochina War and the American role in France’s war effort in North Vietnam.

item.title: Russia’s Lavrov Leads U.N. Peace Meeting, Drawing Accusations of Hypocrisy
item.description: Taking advantage of its turn as president of the Security Council, Moscow sent Foreign Minister Sergey V. Lavrov to preside over a session on peace and diplomacy.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:description: Foreign Minister Sergey V. Lavrov of Russia presiding over a Security Council session on Monday.

item.title: For Many Young Voters, Biden’s Support of Drilling in Alaska Casts Pall
item.description: Despite his aggressive moves to try to slash greenhouse gas emissions, President Biden has angered young climate voters upset by a drilling project in Alaska.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman
item.media:description: A ConocoPhillips drilling site on the North Slope of Alaska. The Willow project, authorized by the Biden administration last month, allowed ConocoPhillips to expand its drilling operations in the area.

item.title: Ukraine’s Spring Offensive Comes With Immense Stakes for Future of the War
item.description: Without a decisive victory, Western support for Ukraine could weaken, and Kyiv could come under increasing pressure to enter serious peace talks to end or freeze the conflict.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes, Eric Schmitt, Adam Entous and Thomas Gibbons-Neff
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Damage in Izium, Ukraine, last week. A failed counteroffensive could lead to waning Western support in Ukraine.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing: China Walks Back Ambassador’s Comments
item.description: Also, Beijing is trying to control chatbots and Thailand prepares for tense elections.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:description: Lu Shaye, China’s ambassador to France, in 2019. On French television on Friday, he said post-Soviet countries “do not have an effective status in international law.”

item.title: German Magazine Editor Is Fired Over Fake Michael Schumacher Interview
item.description: Die Aktuelle promoted an interview as the first with the retired Formula 1 driver since a 2013 accident. But artificial intelligence had generated the responses.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Holpuch
item.media:description: The German magazine Die Aktuelle said its fake interview with the seven-time Formula 1 world champion driver Michael Schumacher was his first since a 2013 skiing accident.

item.title: Statue Is Defaced in England After Children Were Given Crayons
item.description: A memorial and a statue of a water nymph that is more than 200 years old were covered in bright blue crayon marks, officials said.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Holpuch
item.media:description: Bright blue marks were scrawled across the face, arms and torso of the Sabrina statue on April 8, over Easter weekend.

item.title: Putin’s Spokesman, Dmitri Peskov, Claims Son Fought in Ukraine
item.description: Dmitri S. Peskov’s comments highlighted the Moscow elite’s uneven participation in a war that has cost the lives of tens of thousands of Russian soldiers.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev
item.media:description: Dmitri S. Peskov, the Kremlin spokesman, in March.

item.title: How Strong Is the Economy?
item.description: The answer depends on how you measure success.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Brandon Thibodeaux for The New York Times
item.media:description: Austin, Texas.

item.title: The Stealth Campaign That’s Getting Your Kids Hooked on Chess
item.description: Pandemic boredom and a Netflix mini-series, “The Queen’s Gambit,” added to the game’s sudden popularity. But Chess.com was also plotting its own moves.
item.dc:creator: Matt Richtel
item.media:credit: Kim Raff for The New York Times

item.title: China Says Chatbots Must Toe the Party Line
item.description: The Communist Party outlined draft rules that would set guardrails on the rapidly growing industry of services like ChatGPT.
item.dc:creator: Chang Che
item.media:description: Robin Li, the chief executive of Baidu, talking about artificial intelligence in 2018. Baidu and other Chinese tech companies have been racing to catch up with Silicon Valley’s A.I. advances.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing
item.description: Evacuations of foreign officials from Sudan.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: A convoy leaving the Sudanese capital, Khartoum, headed for Port Sudan yesterday.

item.title: Russia’s Wagner Group Has Offered Weapons to R.S.F., U.S. Says
item.description: Wagner has offered powerful weapons, including surface-to-air missiles, to R.S.F. paramilitaries, American officials said.
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt and Edward Wong
item.media:description: Founder of the Wagner private mercenary group, Yevgeny Prigozhin, in Moscow earlier this month.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing: Evacuations from Sudan
item.description: Also, China suppressed Covid-19 data.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: A building damaged during battles between the forces of two rival Sudanese generals in Khartoum, Sudan, on Sunday.

item.title: Bruce Haigh, Diplomat Who Helped Battle Apartheid, Dies at 77
item.description: An Australian, he assisted South African dissidents like the journalist Donald Woods, whose story was told in the movie “Cry Freedom.”
item.dc:creator: Alan Cowell

item.title: Political Chaos Unsettles Israel as It Looks to Honor the Fallen and Its Independence
item.description: Israelis are bracing for a tense Memorial Day and the 75th anniversary of their country’s founding as a political crisis tears it apart.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:credit: Avishag Shaar-Yashuv for The New York Times
item.media:description: Graves of soldiers at Mount Herzl, the location of Israel’s main military cemetery, in Jerusalem.

item.title: Barlocco Island in Scotland Listed for $186,000
item.description: Reaching Barlocco Island is challenging, and staying there for any length of time even more so. Still, dozens are vying for the 25 acres of nature.
item.dc:creator: Remy Tumin

item.title: Baseball Has Changed
item.description: One month into the baseball season, new rules have already had an impact on the game.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Cullen

item.title: Ukraine Says Russian Troops Are Evacuating Civilians From Occupied Areas of South
item.description: Russian troops are forcibly relocating residents near the southern city of Kherson as fighting there intensifies, Ukrainian officials said Sunday.
item.dc:creator: Jeffrey Gettleman and Olha Kotiuzhanska
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mourning Oleksandr Dykiy, 41, a Ukrainian soldier who was killed last week near Bakhmut, at his funeral on Saturday in the village of Liubartsi in the Kyiv region.

item.title: High-Ranking Election Official Is Killed in Myanmar
item.description: A rebel group has claimed responsibility for the attack on an official for the military junta, which comes amid cascading violence on both sides.
item.dc:creator: Richard C. Paddock
item.media:description: Military officers during a parade in Naypyidaw, Myanmar, in March.

item.title: Under Russian Fire, a Ukrainian Soldier Evacuates the Wounded
item.description: Valentyn is a Ukrainian soldier tasked with moving injured troops — and dead bodies — away from the front lines. He described the relentless work of responding to casualties under fire.
item.dc:creator: Yousur Al-Hlou and Masha Froliak

item.title: ‘I Cry Quietly’: A Soldier Describes the Toll of Russia’s War
item.description: For Valentyn, a Ukrainian soldier in the Donetsk region, the war’s death toll is more than a statistic. He is tasked with moving wounded troops — and dead bodies — away from the front lines, often under Russian fire.
item.dc:creator: Yousur Al-Hlou, Masha Froliak and Ben Laffin

item.title: Here are the latest developments.
item.dc:creator: Declan Walsh, Abdi Latif Dahir and Charlie Savage

item.title: In Italy, Leonardo’s Ferry Is Left High and Dry by Global Warming and Red Tape
item.description: A ferry used to traverse the banks of the Adda River, in northern Italy, but drought and an abundance of bureaucracy has closed it down.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.media:credit: Alessandro Grassani for The New York Times
item.media:description: Elementary schoolchildren on a guided tour of the “Leonardo” ferry moored along the Adda River in Imbersago, Italy.

item.title: Elisabeth Kopp, Swiss Politician Who Made History, Dies at 86
item.description: In 1984 she became the first woman elected to the country’s governing council, but a scandal prevented her from being the first woman to serve as president.
item.dc:creator: Neil Genzlinger
item.media:description: Elisabeth Kopp being sworn in as the first female member of the Federal Council, Switzerland’s governing body, in 1984. Her political foes had tried to deny her a seat by stirring up dirt about husband.

item.title: E.P.A. to Propose First Controls on Greenhouse Gases From Power Plants
item.description: If the regulation is implemented, it will be the first time the federal government has limited carbon emissions from existing power plants, which generate 25 percent of U.S. greenhouse gases.
item.dc:creator: Coral Davenport and Lisa Friedman
item.media:credit: Kendrick Brinson for The New York Times
item.media:description: If the proposed regulation is implemented, coal and gas-fired power plants, like the Plant Bowen power station in Georgia, would have to cut their carbon dioxide emissions by 2040

item.title: Western Weapons Supplies Fall Short of Ukraine’s Needs, Documents Show
item.description: Ukraine’s defense minister reported the first U.S.-made Patriot air-defense battery had arrived this week, but secret documents show Kyiv was still waiting for tanks and ammo for its coming counteroffensive.
item.dc:creator: Lara Jakes and John Ismay
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers heading in the direction of the front line last month near Bakhmut, in eastern Ukraine.

item.title: Unlocking the ‘Rosetta Stone’ of a Dying Language
item.description: A member of Canada’s Mohawk community devised a new method to teach an Indigenous language on the brink of extinction.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.category: Six Nations of the Grand River (Ontario)
item.media:credit: Brett Gundlock for The New York Times
item.media:description: Brian Maracle, the founder of a Mohawk language school on the Six Nations of the Grand River territory, southwest of Toronto.

item.title: U.S. Military Evacuates American Embassy in Embattled Sudan
item.description: President Biden announced that diplomatic personnel, who had been stuck in the midst of a brutal war for more than a week, were evacuated from the capital, Khartoum.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Savage, Michael D. Shear, Elian Peltier and Declan Walsh
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Omer Erdem/Anadolu Agency, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Smoke billowing over Sudan’s capital, Khartoum, on Friday.

item.title: Your Spring Soundtrack
item.description: The Morning’s springtime playlist provides an ideal sound for a joyful season.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Kirsch

item.title: Zelensky Signs Law Banning Russian Place Names in Ukraine
item.description: The action late Friday was the latest in a series of steps by Ukraine to distance itself from a long legacy of Russian domination.
item.dc:creator: Jeffrey Gettleman and Olha Kotiuzhanska
item.media:credit: Laetitia Vancon for The New York Times
item.media:description: A pedestal in Kyiv, Ukraine, where a monument to Valery Chkalov, a famous Soviet test pilot, stood before it was taken down.

item.title: No Major Disruption From Public Sector Strike, but Also No Solution in Sight
item.description: The walkout by federal public servants was spurred by inflation and the government’s return-to-office program.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:description: Many public servants are resisting the government’s partial return-to-office plan.

item.title: Russia’s Technocrats Embraced the West, Then Enabled Putin’s War
item.description: The expertise of economic officials who continue to work in the government has helped President Vladimir Putin largely keep the economy afloat in the face of Western sanctions.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev
item.media:description: Arseny Pogosyan, a former energy official who left Russia, arriving at John F. Kennedy International Airport from Cairo.

item.title: An Outsider Takes on Ireland, From Inside a Plastic Bag
item.description: The podcaster behind the popular “Blindboy Podcast,” who earlier gained fame as part of the Rubberbandits hip-hop duo, says that covering his face lets him say things he couldn’t otherwise.
item.dc:creator: Rachel Connolly
item.media:credit: Karen Cox for The New York Times

item.title: As War Rages in Sudan, Countries Angle for Advantage
item.description: Even before its two leading generals went to war last week, “everyone wanted a chunk of Sudan,” an expert said of the strategically located country rich in natural resources.
item.dc:creator: Declan Walsh
item.media:description: Smoke rises over Khartoum, Sudan’s capital, on Friday after almost a week of fighting between warring factions.

item.title: Wreck of Japanese Ship That Sank Carrying Australian POWs is Found
item.description: When the Montevideo Maru sank in the South China Sea during World War II, it was carrying hundreds of prisoners, most of them Australian.
item.dc:creator: Mike Ives
item.media:credit: Australian War Memorial, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The Montevideo Maru in 1941.

item.title: Stern German Judge Supports Legal Pot in Court and Rap Videos
item.description: A social media star with regular appearances on German television, Judge Andreas Müller is unabashed in backing legal marijuana, whether he’s sitting on the bench or playing himself in a music video.
item.dc:creator: Christopher F. Schuetze
item.media:credit: Ilvy Njiokiktjien for The New York Times
item.media:description: Judge Andreas Müller, third from left in cap, on a canal cruise in Amsterdam, before he gave a talk on the status of cannabis legalization in Germany.

item.title: Cellphones Across Britain Will Blast a ‘Loud Siren-like’ Alert This Weekend
item.description: Not everyone is happy about the test warning, which will sound on Sunday at 3 p.m.
item.dc:creator: Jesus Jiménez

item.title: Satellite Images of Sudan Show a Large Food Market Burned in Darfur
item.description: A Times analysis of satellite imagery shows how a displaced persons camp lost a key source of food and supplies amid a fight for control of the country.
item.dc:creator: Christoph Koettl

item.title: Pentagon Speeds Up Tank Timeline for Ukraine but Resists Calls for Jets
item.description: The U.S. will begin training Ukrainian troops on M1 Abrams tanks in the next few weeks, officials said, and combat-ready tanks could reach the battlefields by the fall.
item.dc:creator: Helene Cooper
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: U.S. Army M1A1 Abrams tanks during NATO exercises in 2021 in Latvia.

item.title: Red Cross Expresses Alarm Over Detainee Health at Guantánamo Bay
item.description: As the prisoners age, their physical and mental health needs are increasingly challenging, the leader of a visiting delegation said.
item.dc:creator: Carol Rosenberg
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
International Committee of the Red Cross
item.media:description: A recovery room at the medical clinic in the Camp 5 detention center at Guantánamo Bay.

item.title: Germany Names Panel to Investigate 1972 Munich Olympics Attack
item.description: The commission’s creation stems in part from an agreement made last year to reassess German failures in handling the attack by Palestinian militants, which killed 11 Israeli athletes.
item.dc:creator: Erika Solomon
item.media:description: A member of the Black September Palestinian militant group during the standoff at the Olympic Village in Munich in 1972.

item.title: Canada Lands Volkswagen Battery Plant With Billions in Subsidies
item.description: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau said the assistance was needed to offset incentives offered by the United States.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:description: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau at a news conference on Friday on Volkswagen’s plan for a battery plant in Ontario.

item.title: Alejandro Toledo Returns to Peru Facing Charges in Corruption Case
item.description: Alejandro Toledo, who ruled Peru two decades ago, will be extradited from the United States. He has been charged in one of Latin America’s biggest corruption scandals.
item.dc:creator: Bianca Padró Ocasio
item.media:description: The former Peruvian president Alejandro Toledo during a campaign rally in 2011 in Lima.

item.title: For Earth Day, 7 Inspiring Reads
item.description: We picked some of our favorite articles from the Times’s Climate Desk.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Niki Chan Wylie for The New York Times; Rachelle Baker; Chang W. Lee/The New York Times

item.title: Pentagon Aid Package to Ukraine Includes Old M21 Anti-Tank Mines
item.description: The M21 mines do not run afoul of international treaties. But unlike other mines the United States has given to Kyiv, they can be lethal indefinitely.
item.dc:creator: John Ismay
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: A new weapons package for Ukraine from the Pentagon includes M21 anti-tank land mines.

item.title: Canadian Suspect in Paris Synagogue Bombing Is Found Guilty
item.description: The attack killed four and injured dozens. But decades of false leads, a lack of evidence and legal wrangling delayed a trial.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:description: A police officer at the scene of the attack in the Rue Copernic in Paris in October 1980. It was the first such attack on the French Jewish community since World War II.

item.title: A Radical Experiment in Mental Health Care in Belgium, Tested Over Centuries
item.description: In the Belgian town of Geel, families have long taken in people with psychiatric conditions. Could this approach work elsewhere?
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff, Koba Ryckewaert and Ilvy Njiokiktjien
item.media:description: Ann Peetermans and Iosif, who lives with her as a boarder, feeding a donkey in the backyard of her home in Geel, Belgium.
